Example 

Simplify the expression \(10^{\log_{10} x}\).

Solution

Let \(y=10^{\log_{10} x}\), then take logs (to base \(10\)) of both sides: \[\log_{10} y =\log_{10} (10^{\log_{10} x}) =(\log_{10} x)\log_{10} 10,\] where we have used: \(\log_{10} A^k=k\log_{10} A\). However, since we are using logs to base \(10\), \(\log_{10} 10=1\) and so \(\log_{10} y=\log_{10} x\), which implies \(y=x\).

Therefore, finally we conclude that \(10^{\log_{10} x}=x\).

This is an important result, true for logarithms of any base. It follows from the basic definition of the logarithm.

Key Point 

Raising to the power and taking logs are inverse operations:\[a^{\log_a x}=x,\\ \log_a(a^x) =x.\]
